title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Cells fall into one of two broad categories: prokaryotic and eukaryotic.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: We classify only the predominantly single-celled organisms Bacteria and Archaea as prokaryotes (pro- = “before”; -kary- = “nucleus”).

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Animal cells, plants, fungi, and protists are all eukaryotes (eu- = “true”).

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: All cells share four common components: 1) a plasma membrane, an outer covering that separates the cell’s interior from its surrounding environment; 2) cytoplasm, consisting of a jelly-like cytosol within the cell in which there are other cellular components; 3) DNA, the cell's genetic material; and 4) ribosomes, which synthesize proteins.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: However, prokaryotes differ from eukaryotic cells in several ways.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: A prokaryote is a simple, mostly single-celled (unicellular) organism that lacks a nucleus, or any other membrane-bound organelle.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: We will shortly come to see that this is significantly different in eukaryotes.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Prokaryotic DNA is in the cell's central part: the nucleoid (Figure ).

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Most prokaryotes have a peptidoglycan cell wall and many have a polysaccharide capsule (Figure ).

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: The cell wall acts as an extra layer of protection, helps the cell maintain its shape, and prevents dehydration.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: The capsule enables the cell to attach to surfaces in its environment.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Some prokaryotes have flagella, pili, or fimbriae.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Flagella are used for locomotion.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Pili exchange genetic material during conjugation, the process by which one bacterium transfers genetic material to another through direct contact.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Bacteria use fimbriae to attach to a host cell.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: The most effective action anyone can take to prevent the spread of contagious illnesses is to wash his or her hands.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Because microbes (organisms so tiny that they can only be seen with microscopes) are ubiquitous.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: They live on doorknobs, money, your hands, and many other surfaces.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: If someone sneezes into his hand and touches a doorknob, and afterwards you touch that same doorknob, the microbes from the sneezer’s mucus are now on your hands.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: If you touch your hands to your mouth, nose, or eyes, those microbes can enter your body and could make you sick.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: However, not all microbes (also called microorganisms) cause disease; most are actually beneficial.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: You have microbes in your gut that make vitamin K.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Other microorganisms are used to ferment beer and wine.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Microbiologists are scientists who study microbes.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Microbiologists can pursue a number of careers.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Not only do they work in the food industry, they are also employed in the veterinary and medical fields.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: They can work in the pharmaceutical sector, serving key roles in research and development by identifying new antibiotic sources that can treat bacterial infections.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Environmental microbiologists may look for new ways to use specially selected or genetically engineered microbes to remove pollutants from soil or groundwater, as well as hazardous elements from contaminated sites.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: We call using these microbes bioremediation technologies.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Microbiologists can also work in the bioinformatics field, providing specialized knowledge and insight for designing, developing, and specificity of computer models of, for example, bacterial epidemics.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: At  to  μm in diameter, prokaryotic cells are significantly smaller than eukaryotic cells, which have diameters ranging from 10 to 100 μm (Figure ).

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: The prokaryotes' small size allows ions and organic molecules that enter them to quickly diffuse to other parts of the cell.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Similarly, any wastes produced within a prokaryotic cell can quickly diffuse.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: This is not the case in eukaryotic cells, which have developed different structural adaptations to enhance intracellular transport.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Small size, in general, is necessary for all cells, whether prokaryotic or eukaryotic.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Let’s examine why that is so.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: First, we’ll consider the area and volume of a typical cell.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Not all cells are spherical in shape, but most tend to approximate a sphere.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: You may remember from your high school geometry course that the formula for the surface area of a sphere is 4πr2, while the formula for its volume is 4πr3/3.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Thus, as the radius of a cell increases, its surface area increases as the square of its radius, but its volume increases as the cube of its radius (much more rapidly).

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Therefore, as a cell increases in size, its surface area-to-volume ratio decreases.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: This same principle would apply if the cell had a cube shape (Figure ).

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: If the cell grows too large, the plasma membrane will not have sufficient surface area to support the rate of diffusion required for the increased volume.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: In other words, as a cell grows, it becomes less efficient.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: One way to become more efficient is to divide.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Another way is to develop organelles that perform specific tasks.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: These adaptations lead to developing more sophisticated cells, which we call eukaryotic cells.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: Prokaryotic cells are much smaller than eukaryotic cells.

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: What advantages might small cell size confer on a cell?

title: Prokaryotic Cells
sentence: What advantages might large cell size have?
